      16              : #ifndef OPENSSL_HEADER_BN_H
      17              : #define OPENSSL_HEADER_BN_H
      18              : 
      19              : #include <openssl/base.h>   // IWYU pragma: export

      22              : #include <inttypes.h>  // for PRIu64 and friends

      24              : 
      25              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
      26              : extern "C" {

      28              : 
      29              : 
      30              : // BN provides support for working with arbitrary sized integers. For example,
      31              : // although the largest integer supported by the compiler might be 64 bits, BN
      32              : // will allow you to work with much larger numbers.
      33              : //
      34              : // This library is developed for use inside BoringSSL, and uses implementation
      35              : // strategies that may not be ideal for other applications. Non-cryptographic
      36              : // uses should use a more general-purpose integer library, especially if
      37              : // performance-sensitive.
      38              : //
      39              : // Many functions in BN scale quadratically or higher in the bit length of their
      40              : // input. Callers at this layer are assumed to have capped input sizes within
      41              : // their performance tolerances.
      42              : 
      43              : 
      44              : // BN_ULONG is the native word size when working with big integers.
      45              : //
      46              : // Note: on some platforms, inttypes.h does not define print format macros in
      47              : // C++ unless |__STDC_FORMAT_MACROS| defined. This is due to text in C99 which
      48              : // was never adopted in any C++ standard and explicitly overruled in C++11. As
      49              : // this is a public header, bn.h does not define |__STDC_FORMAT_MACROS| itself.
      50              : // Projects which use |BN_*_FMT*| with outdated C headers may need to define it
      51              : // externally.
      52              : #if defined(OPENSSL_64_BIT)
      53              : typedef uint64_t BN_ULONG;
      54              : #define BN_BITS2 64
      55              : #define BN_DEC_FMT1 "%" PRIu64
      56              : #define BN_HEX_FMT1 "%" PRIx64
      57              : #define BN_HEX_FMT2 "%016" PRIx64
      58              : #elif defined(OPENSSL_32_BIT)
      59              : typedef uint32_t BN_ULONG;
      60              : #define BN_BITS2 32
      61              : #define BN_DEC_FMT1 "%" PRIu32
      62              : #define BN_HEX_FMT1 "%" PRIx32
      63              : #define BN_HEX_FMT2 "%08" PRIx32
      64              : #else
      65              : #error "Must define either OPENSSL_32_BIT or OPENSSL_64_BIT"
      66              : #endif
      67              : 
      68              : 
      69              : // Allocation and freeing.
      70              : 
      71              : // BN_new creates a new, allocated BIGNUM and initialises it.
      72              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_new(void);
      73              : 
      74              : // BN_init initialises a stack allocated |BIGNUM|.
      75              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_init(BIGNUM *bn);
      76              : 
      77              : // BN_free frees the data referenced by |bn| and, if |bn| was originally
      78              : // allocated on the heap, frees |bn| also.
      79              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_free(BIGNUM *bn);
      80              : 
      81              : // BN_clear_free erases and frees the data referenced by |bn| and, if |bn| was
      82              : // originally allocated on the heap, frees |bn| also.
      83              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_clear_free(BIGNUM *bn);
      84              : 
      85              : // BN_dup allocates a new BIGNUM and sets it equal to |src|. It returns the
      86              : // allocated BIGNUM on success or NULL otherwise.
      87              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_dup(const BIGNUM *src);
      88              : 
      89              : // BN_copy sets |dest| equal to |src| and returns |dest| or NULL on allocation
      90              : // failure.
      91              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_copy(BIGNUM *dest, const BIGNUM *src);
      92              : 
      93              : // BN_clear sets |bn| to zero and erases the old data.
      94              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_clear(BIGNUM *bn);
      95              : 
      96              : // BN_value_one returns a static BIGNUM with value 1.
      97              : OPENSSL_EXPORT const BIGNUM *BN_value_one(void);
      98              : 
      99              : 
     100              : // Basic functions.
     101              : 
     102              : // BN_num_bits returns the minimum number of bits needed to represent the
     103              : // absolute value of |bn|.
     104              : OPENSSL_EXPORT unsigned BN_num_bits(const BIGNUM *bn);
     105              : 
     106              : // BN_num_bytes returns the minimum number of bytes needed to represent the
     107              : // absolute value of |bn|.
     108              : //
     109              : // While |size_t| is the preferred type for byte counts, callers can assume that
     110              : // |BIGNUM|s are bounded such that this value, and its corresponding bit count,
     111              : // will always fit in |int|.
     112              : OPENSSL_EXPORT unsigned BN_num_bytes(const BIGNUM *bn);
     113              : 
     114              : // BN_zero sets |bn| to zero.
     115              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_zero(BIGNUM *bn);
     116              : 
     117              : // BN_one sets |bn| to one. It returns one on success or zero on allocation
     118              : // failure.
     119              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_one(BIGNUM *bn);
     120              : 
     121              : // BN_set_word sets |bn| to |value|. It returns one on success or zero on
     122              : // allocation failure.
     123              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_set_word(BIGNUM *bn, BN_ULONG value);
     124              : 
     125              : // BN_set_u64 sets |bn| to |value|. It returns one on success or zero on
     126              : // allocation failure.
     127              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_set_u64(BIGNUM *bn, uint64_t value);
     128              : 
     129              : // BN_set_negative sets the sign of |bn|.
     130              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_set_negative(BIGNUM *bn, int sign);
     131              : 
     132              : // BN_is_negative returns one if |bn| is negative and zero otherwise.
     133              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_negative(const BIGNUM *bn);
     134              : 
     135              : 
     136              : // Conversion functions.
     137              : 
     138              : // BN_bin2bn sets |*ret| to the value of |len| bytes from |in|, interpreted as
     139              : // a big-endian number, and returns |ret|. If |ret| is NULL then a fresh
     140              : // |BIGNUM| is allocated and returned. It returns NULL on allocation
     141              : // failure.
     142              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_bin2bn(const uint8_t *in, size_t len, BIGNUM *ret);
     143              : 
     144              : // BN_bn2bin serialises the absolute value of |in| to |out| as a big-endian
     145              : // integer, which must have |BN_num_bytes| of space available. It returns the
     146              : // number of bytes written. Note this function leaks the magnitude of |in|. If
     147              : // |in| is secret, use |BN_bn2bin_padded| instead.
     148              : OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t BN_bn2bin(const BIGNUM *in, uint8_t *out);
     149              : 
     150              : // BN_lebin2bn sets |*ret| to the value of |len| bytes from |in|, interpreted as
     151              : // a little-endian number, and returns |ret|. If |ret| is NULL then a fresh
     152              : // |BIGNUM| is allocated and returned. It returns NULL on allocation
     153              : // failure.
     154              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_lebin2bn(const uint8_t *in, size_t len, BIGNUM *ret);
     155              : 
     156              : // BN_bn2le_padded serialises the absolute value of |in| to |out| as a
     157              : // little-endian integer, which must have |len| of space available, padding
     158              : // out the remainder of out with zeros. If |len| is smaller than |BN_num_bytes|,
     159              : // the function fails and returns 0. Otherwise, it returns 1.
     160              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_bn2le_padded(uint8_t *out, size_t len, const BIGNUM *in);
     161              : 
     162              : // BN_bn2bin_padded serialises the absolute value of |in| to |out| as a
     163              : // big-endian integer. The integer is padded with leading zeros up to size
     164              : // |len|. If |len| is smaller than |BN_num_bytes|, the function fails and
     165              : // returns 0. Otherwise, it returns 1.
     166              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_bn2bin_padded(uint8_t *out, size_t len, const BIGNUM *in);
     167              : 
     168              : // BN_bn2cbb_padded behaves like |BN_bn2bin_padded| but writes to a |CBB|.
     169              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_bn2cbb_padded(CBB *out, size_t len, const BIGNUM *in);
     170              : 
     171              : // BN_bn2hex returns an allocated string that contains a NUL-terminated, hex
     172              : // representation of |bn|. If |bn| is negative, the first char in the resulting
     173              : // string will be '-'. Returns NULL on allocation failure.
     174              : OPENSSL_EXPORT char *BN_bn2hex(const BIGNUM *bn);
     175              : 
     176              : // BN_hex2bn parses the leading hex number from |in|, which may be proceeded by
     177              : // a '-' to indicate a negative number and may contain trailing, non-hex data.
     178              : // If |outp| is not NULL, it constructs a BIGNUM equal to the hex number and
     179              : // stores it in |*outp|. If |*outp| is NULL then it allocates a new BIGNUM and
     180              : // updates |*outp|. It returns the number of bytes of |in| processed or zero on
     181              : // error.
     182              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_hex2bn(BIGNUM **outp, const char *in);
     183              : 
     184              : // BN_bn2dec returns an allocated string that contains a NUL-terminated,
     185              : // decimal representation of |bn|. If |bn| is negative, the first char in the
     186              : // resulting string will be '-'. Returns NULL on allocation failure.
     187              : //
     188              : // Converting an arbitrarily large integer to decimal is quadratic in the bit
     189              : // length of |a|. This function assumes the caller has capped the input within
     190              : // performance tolerances.
     191              : OPENSSL_EXPORT char *BN_bn2dec(const BIGNUM *a);
     192              : 
     193              : // BN_dec2bn parses the leading decimal number from |in|, which may be
     194              : // proceeded by a '-' to indicate a negative number and may contain trailing,
     195              : // non-decimal data. If |outp| is not NULL, it constructs a BIGNUM equal to the
     196              : // decimal number and stores it in |*outp|. If |*outp| is NULL then it
     197              : // allocates a new BIGNUM and updates |*outp|. It returns the number of bytes
     198              : // of |in| processed or zero on error.
     199              : //
     200              : // Converting an arbitrarily large integer to decimal is quadratic in the bit
     201              : // length of |a|. This function assumes the caller has capped the input within
     202              : // performance tolerances.
     203              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_dec2bn(BIGNUM **outp, const char *in);
     204              : 
     205              : // BN_asc2bn acts like |BN_dec2bn| or |BN_hex2bn| depending on whether |in|
     206              : // begins with "0X" or "0x" (indicating hex) or not (indicating decimal). A
     207              : // leading '-' is still permitted and comes before the optional 0X/0x. It
     208              : // returns one on success or zero on error.
     209              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_asc2bn(BIGNUM **outp, const char *in);
     210              : 
     211              : // BN_print writes a hex encoding of |a| to |bio|. It returns one on success
     212              : // and zero on error.
     213              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_print(BIO *bio, const BIGNUM *a);
     214              : 
     215              : // BN_print_fp acts like |BIO_print|, but wraps |fp| in a |BIO| first.
     216              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_print_fp(FILE *fp, const BIGNUM *a);
     217              : 
     218              : // BN_get_word returns the absolute value of |bn| as a single word. If |bn| is
     219              : // too large to be represented as a single word, the maximum possible value
     220              : // will be returned.
     221              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BN_ULONG BN_get_word(const BIGNUM *bn);
     222              : 
     223              : // BN_get_u64 sets |*out| to the absolute value of |bn| as a |uint64_t| and
     224              : // returns one. If |bn| is too large to be represented as a |uint64_t|, it
     225              : // returns zero.
     226              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_get_u64(const BIGNUM *bn, uint64_t *out);
     227              : 
     228              : 
     229              : // ASN.1 functions.
     230              : 
     231              : // BN_parse_asn1_unsigned parses a non-negative DER INTEGER from |cbs| writes
     232              : // the result to |ret|. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
     233              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_parse_asn1_unsigned(CBS *cbs, BIGNUM *ret);
     234              : 
     235              : // BN_marshal_asn1 marshals |bn| as a non-negative DER INTEGER and appends the
     236              : // result to |cbb|. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
     237              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_marshal_asn1(CBB *cbb, const BIGNUM *bn);
     238              : 
     239              : 
     240              : // BIGNUM pools.
     241              : //
     242              : // Certain BIGNUM operations need to use many temporary variables and
     243              : // allocating and freeing them can be quite slow. Thus such operations typically
     244              : // take a |BN_CTX| parameter, which contains a pool of |BIGNUMs|. The |ctx|
     245              : // argument to a public function may be NULL, in which case a local |BN_CTX|
     246              : // will be created just for the lifetime of that call.
     247              : //
     248              : // A function must call |BN_CTX_start| first. Then, |BN_CTX_get| may be called
     249              : // repeatedly to obtain temporary |BIGNUM|s. All |BN_CTX_get| calls must be made
     250              : // before calling any other functions that use the |ctx| as an argument.
     251              : //
     252              : // Finally, |BN_CTX_end| must be called before returning from the function.
     253              : // When |BN_CTX_end| is called, the |BIGNUM| pointers obtained from
     254              : // |BN_CTX_get| become invalid.
     255              : 
     256              : // BN_CTX_new returns a new, empty BN_CTX or NULL on allocation failure.
     257              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BN_CTX *BN_CTX_new(void);
     258              : 
     259              : // BN_CTX_free frees all BIGNUMs contained in |ctx| and then frees |ctx|
     260              : // itself.
     261              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_CTX_free(BN_CTX *ctx);
     262              : 
     263              : // BN_CTX_start "pushes" a new entry onto the |ctx| stack and allows future
     264              : // calls to |BN_CTX_get|.
     265              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_CTX_start(BN_CTX *ctx);
     266              : 
     267              : // BN_CTX_get returns a new |BIGNUM|, or NULL on allocation failure. Once
     268              : // |BN_CTX_get| has returned NULL, all future calls will also return NULL until
     269              : // |BN_CTX_end| is called.
     270              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_CTX_get(BN_CTX *ctx);
     271              : 
     272              : // BN_CTX_end invalidates all |BIGNUM|s returned from |BN_CTX_get| since the
     273              : // matching |BN_CTX_start| call.
     274              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_CTX_end(BN_CTX *ctx);
     275              : 
     276              : 
     277              : // Simple arithmetic
     278              : 
     279              : // BN_add sets |r| = |a| + |b|, where |r| may be the same pointer as either |a|
     280              : // or |b|. It returns one on success and zero on allocation failure.
     281              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_add(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b);
     282              : 
     283              : // BN_uadd sets |r| = |a| + |b|, considering only the absolute values of |a| and
     284              : // |b|. |r| may be the same pointer as either |a| or |b|. It returns one on
     285              : // success and zero on allocation failure.
     286              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_uadd(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b);
     287              : 
     288              : // BN_add_word adds |w| to |a|. It returns one on success and zero otherwise.
     289              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_add_word(BIGNUM *a, BN_ULONG w);
     290              : 
     291              : // BN_sub sets |r| = |a| - |b|, where |r| may be the same pointer as either |a|
     292              : // or |b|. It returns one on success and zero on allocation failure.
     293              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_sub(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b);
     294              : 
     295              : // BN_usub sets |r| = |a| - |b|, considering only the absolute values of |a| and
     296              : // |b|. The result must be non-negative, i.e. |b| <= |a|. |r| may be the same
     297              : // pointer as either |a| or |b|. It returns one on success and zero on error.
     298              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_usub(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b);
     299              : 
     300              : // BN_sub_word subtracts |w| from |a|. It returns one on success and zero on
     301              : // allocation failure.
     302              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_sub_word(BIGNUM *a, BN_ULONG w);
     303              : 
     304              : // BN_mul sets |r| = |a| * |b|, where |r| may be the same pointer as |a| or
     305              : // |b|. Returns one on success and zero otherwise.
     306              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_mul(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b,
     307              :                           BN_CTX *ctx);
     308              : 
     309              : // BN_mul_word sets |bn| = |bn| * |w|. It returns one on success or zero on
     310              : // allocation failure.
     311              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_mul_word(BIGNUM *bn, BN_ULONG w);
     312              : 
     313              : // BN_sqr sets |r| = |a|^2 (i.e. squares), where |r| may be the same pointer as
     314              : // |a|. Returns one on success and zero otherwise. This is more efficient than
     315              : // BN_mul(r, a, a, ctx).
     316              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_sqr(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, BN_CTX *ctx);
     317              : 
     318              : // BN_div divides |numerator| by |divisor| and places the result in |quotient|
     319              : // and the remainder in |rem|. Either of |quotient| or |rem| may be NULL, in
     320              : // which case the respective value is not returned. It returns one on success or
     321              : // zero on error. It is an error condition if |divisor| is zero.
     322              : //
     323              : // The outputs will be such that |quotient| * |divisor| + |rem| = |numerator|,
     324              : // with the quotient rounded towards zero. Thus, if |numerator| is negative,
     325              : // |rem| will be zero or negative. If |divisor| is negative, the sign of
     326              : // |quotient| will be flipped to compensate but otherwise rounding will be as if
     327              : // |divisor| were its absolute value.
     328              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_div(BIGNUM *quotient, BIGNUM *rem,
     329              :                           const BIGNUM *numerator, const BIGNUM *divisor,
     330              :                           BN_CTX *ctx);
     331              : 
     332              : // BN_div_word sets |numerator| = |numerator|/|divisor| and returns the
     333              : // remainder or (BN_ULONG)-1 on error.
     334              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BN_ULONG BN_div_word(BIGNUM *numerator, BN_ULONG divisor);
     335              : 
     336              : // BN_sqrt sets |*out_sqrt| (which may be the same |BIGNUM| as |in|) to the
     337              : // square root of |in|, using |ctx|. It returns one on success or zero on
     338              : // error. Negative numbers and non-square numbers will result in an error with
     339              : // appropriate errors on the error queue.
     340              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_sqrt(BIGNUM *out_sqrt, const BIGNUM *in, BN_CTX *ctx);
     341              : 
     342              : 
     343              : // Comparison functions
     344              : 
     345              : // BN_cmp returns a value less than, equal to or greater than zero if |a| is
     346              : // less than, equal to or greater than |b|, respectively.
     347              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_cmp(const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b);
     348              : 
     349              : // BN_cmp_word is like |BN_cmp| except it takes its second argument as a
     350              : // |BN_ULONG| instead of a |BIGNUM|.
     351              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_cmp_word(const BIGNUM *a, BN_ULONG b);
     352              : 
     353              : // BN_ucmp returns a value less than, equal to or greater than zero if the
     354              : // absolute value of |a| is less than, equal to or greater than the absolute
     355              : // value of |b|, respectively.
     356              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_ucmp(const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b);
     357              : 
     358              : // BN_equal_consttime returns one if |a| is equal to |b|, and zero otherwise.
     359              : // It takes an amount of time dependent on the sizes of |a| and |b|, but
     360              : // independent of the contents (including the signs) of |a| and |b|.
     361              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_equal_consttime(const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b);
     362              : 
     363              : // BN_abs_is_word returns one if the absolute value of |bn| equals |w| and zero
     364              : // otherwise.
     365              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_abs_is_word(const BIGNUM *bn, BN_ULONG w);
     366              : 
     367              : // BN_is_zero returns one if |bn| is zero and zero otherwise.
     368              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_zero(const BIGNUM *bn);
     369              : 
     370              : // BN_is_one returns one if |bn| equals one and zero otherwise.
     371              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_one(const BIGNUM *bn);
     372              : 
     373              : // BN_is_word returns one if |bn| is exactly |w| and zero otherwise.
     374              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_word(const BIGNUM *bn, BN_ULONG w);
     375              : 
     376              : // BN_is_odd returns one if |bn| is odd and zero otherwise.
     377              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_odd(const BIGNUM *bn);
     378              : 
     379              : // BN_is_pow2 returns 1 if |a| is a power of two, and 0 otherwise.
     380              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_pow2(const BIGNUM *a);
     381              : 
     382              : 
     383              : // Bitwise operations.
     384              : 
     385              : // BN_lshift sets |r| equal to |a| << n. The |a| and |r| arguments may be the
     386              : // same |BIGNUM|. It returns one on success and zero on allocation failure.
     387              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_lshift(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, int n);
     388              : 
     389              : // BN_lshift1 sets |r| equal to |a| << 1, where |r| and |a| may be the same
     390              : // pointer. It returns one on success and zero on allocation failure.
     391              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_lshift1(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a);
     392              : 
     393              : // BN_rshift sets |r| equal to |a| >> n, where |r| and |a| may be the same
     394              : // pointer. It returns one on success and zero on allocation failure.
     395              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_rshift(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, int n);
     396              : 
     397              : // BN_rshift1 sets |r| equal to |a| >> 1, where |r| and |a| may be the same
     398              : // pointer. It returns one on success and zero on allocation failure.
     399              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_rshift1(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a);
     400              : 
     401              : // BN_set_bit sets the |n|th, least-significant bit in |a|. For example, if |a|
     402              : // is 2 then setting bit zero will make it 3. It returns one on success or zero
     403              : // on allocation failure.
     404              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_set_bit(BIGNUM *a, int n);
     405              : 
     406              : // BN_clear_bit clears the |n|th, least-significant bit in |a|. For example, if
     407              : // |a| is 3, clearing bit zero will make it two. It returns one on success or
     408              : // zero on allocation failure.
     409              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_clear_bit(BIGNUM *a, int n);
     410              : 
     411              : // BN_is_bit_set returns one if the |n|th least-significant bit in |a| exists
     412              : // and is set. Otherwise, it returns zero.
     413              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_bit_set(const BIGNUM *a, int n);
     414              : 
     415              : // BN_mask_bits truncates |a| so that it is only |n| bits long. It returns one
     416              : // on success or zero if |n| is negative.
     417              : //
     418              : // This differs from OpenSSL which additionally returns zero if |a|'s word
     419              : // length is less than or equal to |n|, rounded down to a number of words. Note
     420              : // word size is platform-dependent, so this behavior is also difficult to rely
     421              : // on in OpenSSL and not very useful.
     422              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_mask_bits(BIGNUM *a, int n);
     423              : 
     424              : // BN_count_low_zero_bits returns the number of low-order zero bits in |bn|, or
     425              : // the number of factors of two which divide it. It returns zero if |bn| is
     426              : // zero.
     427              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_count_low_zero_bits(const BIGNUM *bn);
     428              : 
     429              :

     434              : 
     435              : // BN_mod_pow2 sets |r| = |a| mod 2^|e|. It returns 1 on success and
     436              : // 0 on error.

     438              :

     441              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_nnmod_pow2(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, size_t e);
     442              : 
     443              : // BN_mod is a helper macro that calls |BN_div| and discards the quotient.
     444              : #define BN_mod(rem, numerator, divisor, ctx) \
     445              :   BN_div(NULL, (rem), (numerator), (divisor), (ctx))
     446              :

     449              : // error.

     502              : 
     503              : // BN_mod_sqrt returns a newly-allocated |BIGNUM|, r, such that
     504              : // r^2 == a (mod p). It returns NULL on error or if |a| is not a square mod |p|.
     505              : // In the latter case, it will add |BN_R_NOT_A_SQUARE| to the error queue.
     506              : // If |a| is a square and |p| > 2, there are two possible square roots. This
     507              : // function may return either and may even select one non-deterministically.
     508              : //
     509              : // This function only works if |p| is a prime. If |p| is composite, it may fail
     510              : // or return an arbitrary value. Callers should not pass attacker-controlled
     511              : // values of |p|.
     512              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_mod_sqrt(BIGNUM *in, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *p,
     513              :                                    BN_CTX *ctx);
     514              : 
     515              : 
     516              : // Random and prime number generation.
     517              : 
     518              : // The following are values for the |top| parameter of |BN_rand|.
     519              : #define BN_RAND_TOP_ANY    (-1)
     520              : #define BN_RAND_TOP_ONE     0
     521              : #define BN_RAND_TOP_TWO     1
     522              : 
     523              : // The following are values for the |bottom| parameter of |BN_rand|.
     524              : #define BN_RAND_BOTTOM_ANY  0
     525              : #define BN_RAND_BOTTOM_ODD  1
     526              : 
     527              : // BN_rand sets |rnd| to a random number of length |bits|. It returns one on
     528              : // success and zero otherwise.
     529              : //
     530              : // |top| must be one of the |BN_RAND_TOP_*| values. If |BN_RAND_TOP_ONE|, the
     531              : // most-significant bit, if any, will be set. If |BN_RAND_TOP_TWO|, the two
     532              : // most significant bits, if any, will be set. If |BN_RAND_TOP_ANY|, no extra
     533              : // action will be taken and |BN_num_bits(rnd)| may not equal |bits| if the most
     534              : // significant bits randomly ended up as zeros.
     535              : //
     536              : // |bottom| must be one of the |BN_RAND_BOTTOM_*| values. If
     537              : // |BN_RAND_BOTTOM_ODD|, the least-significant bit, if any, will be set. If
     538              : // |BN_RAND_BOTTOM_ANY|, no extra action will be taken.
     539              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_rand(BIGNUM *rnd, int bits, int top, int bottom);
     540              : 
     541              : // BN_pseudo_rand is an alias for |BN_rand|.
     542              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_pseudo_rand(BIGNUM *rnd, int bits, int top, int bottom);
     543              : 
     544              : // BN_rand_range is equivalent to |BN_rand_range_ex| with |min_inclusive| set
     545              : // to zero and |max_exclusive| set to |range|.
     546              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_rand_range(BIGNUM *rnd, const BIGNUM *range);
     547              : 
     548              : // BN_rand_range_ex sets |rnd| to a random value in
     549              : // [min_inclusive..max_exclusive). It returns one on success and zero
     550              : // otherwise.
     551              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_rand_range_ex(BIGNUM *r, BN_ULONG min_inclusive,
     552              :                                     const BIGNUM *max_exclusive);
     553              : 
     554              : // BN_pseudo_rand_range is an alias for BN_rand_range.
     555              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_pseudo_rand_range(BIGNUM *rnd, const BIGNUM *range);
     556              : 
     557              : #define BN_GENCB_GENERATED 0
     558              : #define BN_GENCB_PRIME_TEST 1
     559              : 
     560              : // bn_gencb_st, or |BN_GENCB|, holds a callback function that is used by
     561              : // generation functions that can take a very long time to complete. Use
     562              : // |BN_GENCB_set| to initialise a |BN_GENCB| structure.
     563              : //
     564              : // The callback receives the address of that |BN_GENCB| structure as its last
     565              : // argument and the user is free to put an arbitrary pointer in |arg|. The other
     566              : // arguments are set as follows:
     567              : // - event=BN_GENCB_GENERATED, n=i:   after generating the i'th possible prime
     568              : //                                    number.
     569              : // - event=BN_GENCB_PRIME_TEST, n=-1: when finished trial division primality
     570              : //                                    checks.
     571              : // - event=BN_GENCB_PRIME_TEST, n=i:  when the i'th primality test has finished.
     572              : //
     573              : // The callback can return zero to abort the generation progress or one to
     574              : // allow it to continue.
     575              : //
     576              : // When other code needs to call a BN generation function it will often take a
     577              : // BN_GENCB argument and may call the function with other argument values.
     578              : struct bn_gencb_st {
     579              :   void *arg;        // callback-specific data
     580              :   int (*callback)(int event, int n, struct bn_gencb_st *);
     581              : };
     582              : 
     583              : // BN_GENCB_new returns a newly-allocated |BN_GENCB| object, or NULL on
     584              : // allocation failure. The result must be released with |BN_GENCB_free| when
     585              : // done.
     586              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BN_GENCB *BN_GENCB_new(void);
     587              : 
     588              : // BN_GENCB_free releases memory associated with |callback|.
     589              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_GENCB_free(BN_GENCB *callback);
     590              : 
     591              : // BN_GENCB_set configures |callback| to call |f| and sets |callout->arg| to
     592              : // |arg|.
     593              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_GENCB_set(BN_GENCB *callback,
     594              :                                  int (*f)(int event, int n, BN_GENCB *),
     595              :                                  void *arg);
     596              : 
     597              : // BN_GENCB_call calls |callback|, if not NULL, and returns the return value of
     598              : // the callback, or 1 if |callback| is NULL.
     599              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_GENCB_call(BN_GENCB *callback, int event, int n);
     600              : 
     601              : // BN_GENCB_get_arg returns |callback->arg|.
     602              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void *BN_GENCB_get_arg(const BN_GENCB *callback);
     603              : 
     604              : // BN_generate_prime_ex sets |ret| to a prime number of |bits| length. If safe
     605              : // is non-zero then the prime will be such that (ret-1)/2 is also a prime.
     606              : // (This is needed for Diffie-Hellman groups to ensure that the only subgroups
     607              : // are of size 2 and (p-1)/2.).
     608              : //
     609              : // If |add| is not NULL, the prime will fulfill the condition |ret| % |add| ==
     610              : // |rem| in order to suit a given generator. (If |rem| is NULL then |ret| %
     611              : // |add| == 1.)
     612              : //
     613              : // If |cb| is not NULL, it will be called during processing to give an
     614              : // indication of progress. See the comments for |BN_GENCB|. It returns one on
     615              : // success and zero otherwise.
     616              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_generate_prime_ex(BIGNUM *ret, int bits, int safe,
     617              :                                         const BIGNUM *add, const BIGNUM *rem,
     618              :                                         BN_GENCB *cb);
     619              : 
     620              : // BN_prime_checks_for_validation can be used as the |checks| argument to the
     621              : // primarily testing functions when validating an externally-supplied candidate
     622              : // prime. It gives a false positive rate of at most 2^{-128}. (The worst case
     623              : // false positive rate for a single iteration is 1/4 per
     624              : // https://eprint.iacr.org/2018/749. (1/4)^64 = 2^{-128}.)
     625              : #define BN_prime_checks_for_validation 64
     626              : 
     627              : // BN_prime_checks_for_generation can be used as the |checks| argument to the
     628              : // primality testing functions when generating random primes. It gives a false
     629              : // positive rate at most the security level of the corresponding RSA key size.
     630              : //
     631              : // Note this value only performs enough checks if the candidate prime was
     632              : // selected randomly. If validating an externally-supplied candidate, especially
     633              : // one that may be selected adversarially, use |BN_prime_checks_for_validation|
     634              : // instead.
     635              : #define BN_prime_checks_for_generation 0
     636              : 
     637              : // bn_primality_result_t enumerates the outcomes of primality-testing.
     638              : enum bn_primality_result_t {
     639              :   bn_probably_prime,
     640              :   bn_composite,
     641              :   bn_non_prime_power_composite,
     642              : };
     643              : 
     644              : // BN_enhanced_miller_rabin_primality_test tests whether |w| is probably a prime
     645              : // number using the Enhanced Miller-Rabin Test (FIPS 186-4 C.3.2) with
     646              : // |checks| iterations and returns the result in |out_result|. Enhanced
     647              : // Miller-Rabin tests primality for odd integers greater than 3, returning
     648              : // |bn_probably_prime| if the number is probably prime,
     649              : // |bn_non_prime_power_composite| if the number is a composite that is not the
     650              : // power of a single prime, and |bn_composite| otherwise. It returns one on
     651              : // success and zero on failure. If |cb| is not NULL, then it is called during
     652              : // each iteration of the primality test.
     653              : //
     654              : // See |BN_prime_checks_for_validation| and |BN_prime_checks_for_generation| for
     655              : // recommended values of |checks|.
     656              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_enhanced_miller_rabin_primality_test(
     657              :     enum bn_primality_result_t *out_result, const BIGNUM *w, int checks,
     658              :     BN_CTX *ctx, BN_GENCB *cb);
     659              : 
     660              : // BN_primality_test sets |*is_probably_prime| to one if |candidate| is
     661              : // probably a prime number by the Miller-Rabin test or zero if it's certainly
     662              : // not.
     663              : //
     664              : // If |do_trial_division| is non-zero then |candidate| will be tested against a
     665              : // list of small primes before Miller-Rabin tests. The probability of this
     666              : // function returning a false positive is at most 2^{2*checks}. See
     667              : // |BN_prime_checks_for_validation| and |BN_prime_checks_for_generation| for
     668              : // recommended values of |checks|.
     669              : //
     670              : // If |cb| is not NULL then it is called during the checking process. See the
     671              : // comment above |BN_GENCB|.
     672              : //
     673              : // The function returns one on success and zero on error.
     674              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_primality_test(int *is_probably_prime,
     675              :                                      const BIGNUM *candidate, int checks,
     676              :                                      BN_CTX *ctx, int do_trial_division,
     677              :                                      BN_GENCB *cb);
     678              : 
     679              : // BN_is_prime_fasttest_ex returns one if |candidate| is probably a prime
     680              : // number by the Miller-Rabin test, zero if it's certainly not and -1 on error.
     681              : //
     682              : // If |do_trial_division| is non-zero then |candidate| will be tested against a
     683              : // list of small primes before Miller-Rabin tests. The probability of this
     684              : // function returning one when |candidate| is composite is at most 2^{2*checks}.
     685              : // See |BN_prime_checks_for_validation| and |BN_prime_checks_for_generation| for
     686              : // recommended values of |checks|.
     687              : //
     688              : // If |cb| is not NULL then it is called during the checking process. See the
     689              : // comment above |BN_GENCB|.
     690              : //
     691              : // WARNING: deprecated. Use |BN_primality_test|.
     692              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_prime_fasttest_ex(const BIGNUM *candidate, int checks,
     693              :                                            BN_CTX *ctx, int do_trial_division,
     694              :                                            BN_GENCB *cb);
     695              : 
     696              : // BN_is_prime_ex acts the same as |BN_is_prime_fasttest_ex| with
     697              : // |do_trial_division| set to zero.
     698              : //
     699              : // WARNING: deprecated: Use |BN_primality_test|.
     700              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_is_prime_ex(const BIGNUM *candidate, int checks,
     701              :                                   BN_CTX *ctx, BN_GENCB *cb);
     702              : 
     703              : 
     704              : // Number theory functions
     705              : 
     706              : // BN_gcd sets |r| = gcd(|a|, |b|). It returns one on success and zero
     707              : // otherwise.
     708              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_gcd(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *b,
     709              :                           BN_CTX *ctx);
     710              : 
     711              : // BN_mod_inverse sets |out| equal to |a|^-1, mod |n|. If |out| is NULL, a
     712              : // fresh BIGNUM is allocated. It returns the result or NULL on error.
     713              : //
     714              : // If |n| is even then the operation is performed using an algorithm that avoids
     715              : // some branches but which isn't constant-time. This function shouldn't be used
     716              : // for secret values; use |BN_mod_inverse_blinded| instead. Or, if |n| is
     717              : // guaranteed to be prime, use
     718              : // |BN_mod_exp_mont_consttime(out, a, m_minus_2, m, ctx, m_mont)|, taking
     719              : // advantage of Fermat's Little Theorem.
     720              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_mod_inverse(BIGNUM *out, const BIGNUM *a,
     721              :                                       const BIGNUM *n, BN_CTX *ctx);
     722              : 
     723              : // BN_mod_inverse_blinded sets |out| equal to |a|^-1, mod |n|, where |n| is the
     724              : // Montgomery modulus for |mont|. |a| must be non-negative and must be less
     725              : // than |n|. |n| must be greater than 1. |a| is blinded (masked by a random
     726              : // value) to protect it against side-channel attacks. On failure, if the failure
     727              : // was caused by |a| having no inverse mod |n| then |*out_no_inverse| will be
     728              : // set to one; otherwise it will be set to zero.
     729              : //
     730              : // Note this function may incorrectly report |a| has no inverse if the random
     731              : // blinding value has no inverse. It should only be used when |n| has few
     732              : // non-invertible elements, such as an RSA modulus.
     733              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_mod_inverse_blinded(BIGNUM *out, int *out_no_inverse,
     734              :                                           const BIGNUM *a,
     735              :                                           const BN_MONT_CTX *mont, BN_CTX *ctx);
     736              : 
     737              : // BN_mod_inverse_odd sets |out| equal to |a|^-1, mod |n|. |a| must be
     738              : // non-negative and must be less than |n|. |n| must be odd. This function
     739              : // shouldn't be used for secret values; use |BN_mod_inverse_blinded| instead.
     740              : // Or, if |n| is guaranteed to be prime, use
     741              : // |BN_mod_exp_mont_consttime(out, a, m_minus_2, m, ctx, m_mont)|, taking
     742              : // advantage of Fermat's Little Theorem. It returns one on success or zero on
     743              : // failure. On failure, if the failure was caused by |a| having no inverse mod
     744              : // |n| then |*out_no_inverse| will be set to one; otherwise it will be set to
     745              : // zero.
     746              : int BN_mod_inverse_odd(BIGNUM *out, int *out_no_inverse, const BIGNUM *a,
     747              :                        const BIGNUM *n, BN_CTX *ctx);
     748              : 
     749              : 
     750              : // Montgomery arithmetic.
     751              : 
     752              : // BN_MONT_CTX contains the precomputed values needed to work in a specific
     753              : // Montgomery domain.
     754              : 
     755              : // BN_MONT_CTX_new_for_modulus returns a fresh |BN_MONT_CTX| given the modulus,
     756              : // |mod| or NULL on error. Note this function assumes |mod| is public.
     757              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BN_MONT_CTX *BN_MONT_CTX_new_for_modulus(const BIGNUM *mod,
     758              :                                                         BN_CTX *ctx);
     759              : 
     760              : // BN_MONT_CTX_new_consttime behaves like |BN_MONT_CTX_new_for_modulus| but
     761              : // treats |mod| as secret.
     762              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BN_MONT_CTX *BN_MONT_CTX_new_consttime(const BIGNUM *mod,
     763              :                                                       BN_CTX *ctx);
     764              : 
     765              : // BN_MONT_CTX_free frees memory associated with |mont|.
     766              : OPENSSL_EXPORT void BN_MONT_CTX_free(BN_MONT_CTX *mont);
     767              : 
     768              : // BN_MONT_CTX_copy sets |to| equal to |from|. It returns |to| on success or
     769              : // NULL on error.
     770              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BN_MONT_CTX *BN_MONT_CTX_copy(BN_MONT_CTX *to,
     771              :                                              const BN_MONT_CTX *from);
     772              : 
     773              : // BN_to_montgomery sets |ret| equal to |a| in the Montgomery domain. |a| is
     774              : // assumed to be in the range [0, n), where |n| is the Montgomery modulus. It
     775              : // returns one on success or zero on error.
     776              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_to_montgomery(BIGNUM *ret, const BIGNUM *a,
     777              :                                     const BN_MONT_CTX *mont, BN_CTX *ctx);
     778              : 
     779              : // BN_from_montgomery sets |ret| equal to |a| * R^-1, i.e. translates values out
     780              : // of the Montgomery domain. |a| is assumed to be in the range [0, n*R), where
     781              : // |n| is the Montgomery modulus. Note n < R, so inputs in the range [0, n*n)
     782              : // are valid. This function returns one on success or zero on error.
     783              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_from_montgomery(BIGNUM *ret, const BIGNUM *a,
     784              :                                       const BN_MONT_CTX *mont, BN_CTX *ctx);
     785              : 
     786              : // BN_mod_mul_montgomery set |r| equal to |a| * |b|, in the Montgomery domain.
     787              : // Both |a| and |b| must already be in the Montgomery domain (by
     788              : // |BN_to_montgomery|). In particular, |a| and |b| are assumed to be in the
     789              : // range [0, n), where |n| is the Montgomery modulus. It returns one on success
     790              : // or zero on error.
     791              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_mod_mul_montgomery(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a,
     792              :                                          const BIGNUM *b,
     793              :                                          const BN_MONT_CTX *mont, BN_CTX *ctx);
     794              : 
     795              : 
     796              : // Exponentiation.
     797              : 
     798              : // BN_exp sets |r| equal to |a|^{|p|}. It does so with a square-and-multiply
     799              : // algorithm that leaks side-channel information. It returns one on success or
     800              : // zero otherwise.
     801              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_exp(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *p,
     802              :                           BN_CTX *ctx);
     803              : 
     804              : // BN_mod_exp sets |r| equal to |a|^{|p|} mod |m|. It does so with the best
     805              : // algorithm for the values provided. It returns one on success or zero
     806              : // otherwise. The |BN_mod_exp_mont_consttime| variant must be used if the
     807              : // exponent is secret.
     808              : OPENSSL_EXPORT int BN_mod_exp(BIGNUM *r, const BIGNUM *a, const BIGNUM *p,
     809              :                               const BIGNUM *m, BN_CTX *ctx);
     810              : 
     811              : // BN_mod_exp_mont behaves like |BN_mod_exp| but treats |a| as secret and
     812              : // requires 0 <= |a| < |m|.

     814              :                                    const BIGNUM *m, BN_CTX *ctx,

     817              : // BN_mod_exp_mont_consttime behaves like |BN_mod_exp| but treats |a|, |p|, and

     825              : // Deprecated functions
     826              : 
     827              : // BN_bn2mpi serialises the value of |in| to |out|, using a format that consists
     828              : // of the number's length in bytes represented as a 4-byte big-endian number,
     829              : // and the number itself in big-endian format, where the most significant bit
     830              : // signals a negative number. (The representation of numbers with the MSB set is
     831              : // prefixed with null byte). |out| must have sufficient space available; to
     832              : // find the needed amount of space, call the function with |out| set to NULL.
     833              : OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t BN_bn2mpi(const BIGNUM *in, uint8_t *out);
     834              : 
     835              : // BN_mpi2bn parses |len| bytes from |in| and returns the resulting value. The
     836              : // bytes at |in| are expected to be in the format emitted by |BN_bn2mpi|.
     837              : //
     838              : // If |out| is NULL then a fresh |BIGNUM| is allocated and returned, otherwise
     839              : // |out| is reused and returned. On error, NULL is returned and the error queue
     840              : // is updated.
     841              : OPENSSL_EXPORT BIGNUM *BN_mpi2bn(const uint8_t *in, size_t len, BIGNUM *out);

     843              : // BN_mod_exp_mont_word is like |BN_mod_exp_mont| except that the base |a| is
     844              : // given as a |BN_ULONG| instead of a |BIGNUM *|. It returns one on success
     845              : // or zero otherwise.

     892              : // Private functions
     893              : 
     894              : struct bignum_st {
     895              :   // d is a pointer to an array of |width| |BN_BITS2|-bit chunks in
     896              :   // little-endian order. This stores the absolute value of the number.
     897              :   BN_ULONG *d;
     898              :   // width is the number of elements of |d| which are valid. This value is not
     899              :   // necessarily minimal; the most-significant words of |d| may be zero.
     900              :   // |width| determines a potentially loose upper-bound on the absolute value
     901              :   // of the |BIGNUM|.
     902              :   //
     903              :   // Functions taking |BIGNUM| inputs must compute the same answer for all
     904              :   // possible widths. |bn_minimal_width|, |bn_set_minimal_width|, and other
     905              :   // helpers may be used to recover the minimal width, provided it is not
     906              :   // secret. If it is secret, use a different algorithm. Functions may output
     907              :   // minimal or non-minimal |BIGNUM|s depending on secrecy requirements, but
     908              :   // those which cause widths to unboundedly grow beyond the minimal value
     909              :   // should be documented such.
     910              :   //
     911              :   // Note this is different from historical |BIGNUM| semantics.
     912              :   int width;
     913              :   // dmax is number of elements of |d| which are allocated.
     914              :   int dmax;
     915              :   // neg is one if the number if negative and zero otherwise.
     916              :   int neg;
     917              :   // flags is a bitmask of |BN_FLG_*| values
     918              :   int flags;
     919              : };
     920              : 
     921              : struct bn_mont_ctx_st {
     922              :   // RR is R^2, reduced modulo |N|. It is used to convert to Montgomery form. It
     923              :   // is guaranteed to have the same width as |N|.
     924              :   BIGNUM RR;
     925              :   // N is the modulus. It is always stored in minimal form, so |N.width|
     926              :   // determines R.
     927              :   BIGNUM N;
     928              :   BN_ULONG n0[2];  // least significant words of (R*Ri-1)/N
     929              : };
     930              : 
     931              : OPENSSL_EXPORT unsigned BN_num_bits_word(BN_ULONG l);
     932              : 
     933              : #define BN_FLG_MALLOCED 0x01
     934              : #define BN_FLG_STATIC_DATA 0x02
     935              : // |BN_FLG_CONSTTIME| has been removed and intentionally omitted so code relying
     936              : // on it will not compile. Consumers outside BoringSSL should use the
     937              : // higher-level cryptographic algorithms exposed by other modules. Consumers
     938              : // within the library should call the appropriate timing-sensitive algorithm
     939              : // directly.
     940              : 
     941              : 
     942              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
     943              : }  // extern C
     944              : 
     945              : #if !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
